block.p: Tension Mounts in Kashmir As Pakistan Moves Troops President Bush said that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld would be sent to India and Pakistan in an effort to defuse the growing threat of nuclear war. Mr. Bush made his strongest demand yet that Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, crack down on the infiltration of terrorists into India.

Pakistan's president said troops would be withdrawn from the border of Afghanistan and stationed in the increasingly volatile region of Kashmir, while reiterating that his country would not initiate a war against India in the disputed region.

Afghan Prisoners Released American forces released 50 of 55 Afghan prisoners and the body of their tribal leader after six days of negotiation.

Effort to End Mideast Impasse Foreign diplomats began arriving in Jerusalem in an effort to break the impasse between Israel and the Palestinians. Israel arrested a Palestinian man and his Jewish Israeli wife as prime suspects in helping organize the May 22 suicide bombing in Rishon le Zion. Israeli tanks and armored personnel carriers moved into the West Bank city of Hebron.

Ethical Crisis in Canada Prime Minister Jean Chr√©tien has frozen dozens of government contracts, reorganized his cabinet and issued new rules on political donations and conflicts of interest amid the worst ethics controversy to face his party in years.

Dutch Warning on Extremists Security officials said a network of Islamic extremists has been recruiting among young Muslim immigrants in the Netherlands to join the fighting in places like Afghanistan or Kashmir.
Britain Tightens Borders Officials said the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum bill now moving through Parliament would result in a tightening of immigration laws.

Ashcroft Loosens Reins On F.B.I to Fight Terrorism Attorney General John Ashcroft said he was bolstering the fight against terrorism by expanding the bureau's authority to monitor the Worldwide Web, political groups, libraries and religious organizations, including houses of worship like mosques.

Bioterror Vaccine on Fast Track The F.D.A. said it would allow some drugs and vaccines designed to counter biological or chemical terrorism to be approved without having to be tested in people. Government officials and pharmaceutical industry executives said the new rule could spur development of drugs to be used against biological, chemical and radioactive substances.
Video Surveillance for Airliners The Transportation Department is considering requiring video cameras that will provide images of passengers to the cockpit.

Church Group Seeks Democracy Voice of the Faithful, a group of lay Roman Catholics formed in Massachusetts four months ago by about two dozen parishioners discussing the sex abuse scandal, has mushroomed into an organization claiming nearly 10,000 members from about 40 states and 21 countries. The group aims to establishing a small degree of democracy in a church that has long resisted it.

Campaign Finance Concerns The principal sponsors of the new campaign finance law have told the Federal Election Commission that its proposed regulations for the campaign system ''would severely undermine the new law.''

Climate Satellite Malfunctions A vital instrument on a new billion-dollar satellite designed to resolve questions about the changing climate is malfunctioning, NASA officials said. The satellite, called Aqua, is the centerpiece of a suite of satellites and projects intended to improve forecasting and gather data on the human role in global warming.

Solemn Ceremony Ends Grim Task at Ground Zero At 10:29 a.m., after the tolling of bells and in the presence of thousands, silence took its proper place at the World Trade Center site. A corner of the city became still, as a stretcher bearing the weight of no body was carried out of the swept-clean pit where the twin towers once stood, followed by a truck carting a 58-ton steel column -- the last symbolic remnant of what was, before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. ''It seems like yesterday,'' said Alan Reiss, a stretcher bearer who was the Port Authority's operations liaison at the trade center. ''And here we are, and it's the end of May.''

Tribute to Lou Gehrig James Gandolfini of ''The Sopranos'' will read Lou Gehrig's famous farewell speech at Yankee Stadium on Saturday to commemorate the anniversary of Gehrig's death in 1941 from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Celebrities will read the speech at 14 ballparks as Major League Baseball holds Project A.L.S. Day.

Bringing Joyce Back Home The National Library of Ireland has bought 700 pages of manuscripts by James Joyce, including 16 drafts from ''Ulysses'' and and proofs of ''Finnegans Wake.'' Discovered two years ago, they were kept secret until the announcement of the sale, which is a sort of homecoming for Ireland's most famous exile. The acquisition, for $11.7 million through Sotheby's in London, is the largest artistic purchase ever made by the Irish state.
Lois Gould A best-selling novelist, essayist and memoirist known for her acutely observed portrayals of the emotional complexities of women's lives, she was 70.

Global Crossing Fallout The collapse of an agreement for two Asian companies to make a bid for Global Crossing is being tied to actions by J.P. Morgan Chase that may have soured the transaction, people close to Global Crossing said. J.P. Morgan is the leader of a group of banks facing losses on more than $2 billion in loans to Global Crossing, the communications company that filed for bankruptcy protection.

Acid Rain Reductions The United States government estimated that the 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act to cut pollution from power plants would cost companies up to $15 billion a year, but the generators have cut emissions for a fraction of that amount.
Miller Time in South Africa South African Breweries agreed to buy the Miller Brewing Company from Philip Morris for $3.6 billion.
